description: Comprehensive trivia database with research-based questions

questions.question: Who was the first US president to resign from office?
questions.explanation: Richard Nixon resigned on August 9, 1974 due to the Watergate scandal.

questions.question: Which president is on the $100 bill?
questions.explanation: Trick question - Benjamin Franklin was never president. The $100 bill features Franklin, but he was a Founding Father, not a president.

questions.question: Who was the only president to serve more than two terms?
questions.explanation: FDR served four terms from 1933-1945. The 22nd Amendment now limits presidents to two terms.

questions.question: Which president purchased Alaska from Russia?
questions.explanation: Alaska was purchased in 1867 for $7.2 million during Andrew Johnson's presidency. It was called "Seward's Folly" after Secretary of State William Seward.

questions.question: Who was president during the Louisiana Purchase?
questions.explanation: Thomas Jefferson purchased Louisiana from France in 1803 for $15 million, doubling the size of the US.

questions.question: Which president was a famous general in World War II?
questions.explanation: Eisenhower was Supreme Allied Commander in Europe during WWII before becoming the 34th president.

questions.question: Who was the tallest US president?
questions.explanation: Lincoln stood 6 feet 4 inches tall, the tallest of all US presidents.

questions.question: Which president appears on the nickel?
questions.explanation: Thomas Jefferson is featured on the US nickel (5-cent coin).

questions.question: Who was the youngest person to become president?
questions.explanation: Teddy Roosevelt became president at age 42 after McKinley's assassination. JFK was the youngest elected at 43.

questions.question: Which president created the New Deal?
questions.explanation: FDR created the New Deal programs to combat the Great Depression in the 1930s.

questions.question: What year did World War I begin?
questions.explanation: World War I began in 1914 and ended in 1918, lasting 4 years.

questions.question: What was the name of the treaty that ended WWI?
questions.explanation: The Treaty of Versailles was signed in 1919, officially ending WWI. Its harsh terms on Germany contributed to WWII.

questions.question: Which country was NOT part of the Axis powers in WWII?
questions.explanation: The Axis powers were Germany, Italy, and Japan. The Soviet Union was part of the Allies.

questions.question: What was D-Day?
questions.explanation: D-Day (June 6, 1944) was the Allied invasion of Normandy, France - the largest amphibious assault in history.

questions.question: Who was the British Prime Minister during most of WWII?
questions.explanation: Winston Churchill led Britain through most of WWII, famous for his "We shall never surrender" speech.

questions.question: What was the code name for the atomic bomb project?
questions.explanation: The Manhattan Project was the secret US project that developed the atomic bomb during WWII.

questions.question: Where did the D-Day invasion take place?
questions.explanation: The D-Day invasion occurred on the beaches of Normandy in northern France.

questions.question: What ship's sinking helped bring the US into WWI?
questions.explanation: The British passenger ship Lusitania was sunk by a German U-boat in 1915, killing 128 Americans and influencing US entry into WWI.

questions.question: What was the last major German offensive in WWII?
questions.explanation: The Battle of the Bulge (December 1944-January 1945) was Germany's last major offensive on the Western Front.

questions.question: What year did the US drop atomic bombs on Japan?
questions.explanation: The US dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima (August 6) and Nagasaki (August 9) in 1945, ending WWII.

questions.question: Who built the Great Pyramid of Giza?
questions.explanation: The Great Pyramid was built for Pharaoh Khufu around 2560 BC. It's the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.

questions.question: What year did Julius Caesar die?
questions.explanation: Julius Caesar was assassinated on March 15 (the Ides of March), 44 BC by Roman senators.

questions.question: Who was the first Roman Emperor?
questions.explanation: Augustus (formerly Octavian) became the first Roman Emperor in 27 BC after the civil war that followed Caesar's death.

questions.question: What ancient wonder was located in Alexandria?
questions.explanation: The Lighthouse of Alexandria (Pharos) was one of the Seven Wonders. The Library of Alexandria was also there but not a "wonder".

questions.question: Who founded the Mongol Empire?
questions.explanation: Genghis Khan founded and led the Mongol Empire, which became the largest contiguous empire in history.

questions.question: What year did the Roman Empire fall?
questions.explanation: 476 AD marks the fall of the Western Roman Empire when Romulus Augustulus was deposed. The Eastern (Byzantine) Empire continued until 1453.

questions.question: Who was the last pharaoh of Egypt?
questions.explanation: Cleopatra VII was Egypt's last pharaoh. After her death in 30 BC, Egypt became a Roman province.

questions.question: What city did Alexander the Great NOT conquer?
questions.explanation: Alexander the Great conquered much of the known world but never reached Rome. He died at 32 before expanding westward.

questions.question: What was the name of the Greek formation of soldiers with spears?
questions.explanation: The phalanx was a rectangular military formation of infantry with overlapping shields and spears.

questions.question: Which Roman emperor made Christianity legal?
questions.explanation: Emperor Constantine issued the Edict of Milan in 313 AD, legalizing Christianity in the Roman Empire.

questions.question: What year did Columbus reach the Americas?
questions.explanation: Christopher Columbus reached the Caribbean in 1492, sponsored by Spain.

questions.question: Who led the Norman conquest of England?
questions.explanation: William defeated Harold II at the Battle of Hastings in 1066.

questions.question: What city was the center of the Renaissance?
questions.explanation: Florence, Italy was the birthplace of the Renaissance in the 14th-16th centuries.

questions.question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
questions.explanation: Da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa around 1503-1519 during the Italian Renaissance.

questions.question: What year did the Black Death begin in Europe?
questions.explanation: The bubonic plague reached Europe in 1347, killing 30-60% of the population.

questions.question: Who invented the printing press?
questions.explanation: Gutenberg invented movable type printing around 1440 in Germany.

questions.question: What was the Protestant Reformation?
questions.explanation: Started by Martin Luther in 1517, challenging Catholic Church authority.

questions.question: Who was Joan of Arc?
questions.explanation: Joan led French forces during the Hundred Years War before being burned at the stake in 1431.

questions.question: What empire did Constantinople belong to?
questions.explanation: Constantinople was the Byzantine capital until conquered by Ottomans in 1453.

questions.question: Who wrote The Canterbury Tales?
questions.explanation: Chaucer wrote The Canterbury Tales in Middle English in the late 14th century.

questions.question: What year did the Berlin Wall fall?
questions.explanation: The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, symbolizing the end of the Cold War.

questions.question: Who was the first man on the moon?
questions.explanation: Armstrong stepped on the moon on July 20, 1969 during the Apollo 11 mission.

questions.question: What year did the Soviet Union collapse?
questions.explanation: The USSR officially dissolved on December 26, 1991, ending 69 years of communist rule.

questions.question: Who was the British Prime Minister during the Falklands War?
questions.explanation: Thatcher led Britain during the 1982 Falklands War against Argentina.

questions.question: What was the Cuban Missile Crisis?
questions.explanation: A 13-day confrontation between US and USSR over Soviet missiles in Cuba, nearly causing nuclear war.

questions.question: Who assassinated JFK?
questions.explanation: Oswald shot President Kennedy in Dallas on November 22, 1963.

questions.question: What was the Vietnam War about?
questions.explanation: US fought from 1965-1973 to prevent communist takeover of South Vietnam.

questions.question: What year did apartheid end in South Africa?
questions.explanation: Apartheid officially ended in 1994 with the first multi-racial elections won by Nelson Mandela.

questions.question: Who was the last emperor of China?
questions.explanation: Puyi abdicated in 1912, ending the Qing Dynasty and thousands of years of imperial rule.

questions.question: What was the Bay of Pigs invasion?
questions.explanation: In 1961, CIA-backed Cuban exiles failed to overthrow Castro, embarrassing the Kennedy administration.

questions.question: What event triggered the start of WWI?
questions.explanation: The 1914 assassination in Sarajevo set off a chain reaction of alliances leading to war.

questions.question: What was the Manhattan Project?
questions.explanation: US program during WWII that developed the first nuclear weapons.

questions.question: Who was the first female Prime Minister of the UK?
questions.explanation: Thatcher served from 1979-1990, earning the nickname "Iron Lady".

questions.question: What was the Great Depression?
questions.explanation: Began with the 1929 stock market crash, lasted through the 1930s.

questions.question: Who led the Soviet Union during most of WWII?
questions.explanation: Stalin led from 1924-1953, transforming USSR into a superpower.

questions.question: What was the Marshall Plan?
questions.explanation: After WWII, US provided $13 billion to help rebuild Western European economies.

questions.question: Who wrote the "I Have a Dream" speech?
questions.explanation: King delivered the speech during the 1963 March on Washington.

questions.question: What was the Watergate scandal?
questions.answer: Political scandal that ended Nixon presidency
questions.explanation: Break-in at Democratic headquarters in 1972 led to Nixon's resignation.

questions.question: Who was the first woman elected to Congress?
questions.explanation: Rankin of Montana was elected in 1916, before women had the right to vote nationally.

questions.question: What was the Space Race?
questions.explanation: Competition peaked with the 1969 moon landing by the US.

questions.question: What is the largest organ in the human body?
questions.explanation: The skin is the largest organ, covering about 20 square feet and weighing 8-10 pounds in adults.

questions.question: How many bones are in the adult human body?
questions.explanation: Adults have 206 bones. Babies are born with about 300, but many fuse together as we grow.

questions.question: What is the hardest substance in the human body?
questions.explanation: Tooth enamel is harder than bone. It's made mostly of calcium phosphate.

questions.question: What blood type is the universal donor?
questions.explanation: O negative blood can be given to anyone, making it the universal donor type.

questions.question: How many chambers does the human heart have?
questions.explanation: The heart has 4 chambers: left atrium, right atrium, left ventricle, right ventricle.

questions.question: What is the smallest bone in the human body?
questions.explanation: The stapes in the middle ear is only 2-3 millimeters long.

questions.question: What percentage of the human body is water?
questions.explanation: The human body is approximately 60% water, varying by age and body composition.

questions.question: What is the largest muscle in the human body?
questions.explanation: The gluteus maximus (buttock muscle) is the largest muscle in the body.

questions.question: How many taste buds does the average human have?
questions.explanation: Humans have approximately 10,000 taste buds that detect sweet, sour, salty, bitter, and umami.

questions.question: What is the largest artery in the human body?
questions.explanation: The aorta is the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body.

questions.question: What is the longest bone in the human body?
questions.explanation: The femur is about 1/4 of your total height and the strongest bone.

questions.question: How long does it take for blood to circulate the body?
questions.explanation: Blood makes a complete circuit through the body in roughly one minute.

questions.question: What is the average human body temperature?
questions.explanation: Normal body temperature is 98.6°F, though it varies slightly throughout the day.

questions.question: How many lungs does a human have?
questions.explanation: Humans have two lungs: right lung has 3 lobes, left lung has 2 lobes.

questions.question: What is the largest internal organ?
questions.explanation: The liver weighs about 3 pounds and performs over 500 functions.

questions.question: What is the fastest land animal?
questions.explanation: Cheetahs can reach speeds up to 70 mph, making them the fastest land animal.

questions.question: What is the largest animal ever to exist?
questions.explanation: Blue whales can grow up to 100 feet long and weigh 200 tons - larger than any dinosaur.

questions.question: How many hearts does an octopus have?
questions.explanation: Octopuses have 3 hearts: two pump blood to the gills, one pumps it to the body.

questions.question: What is the only mammal that can fly?
questions.explanation: Bats are the only mammals capable of true sustained flight.

questions.question: What animal has the longest lifespan?
questions.explanation: Greenland sharks can live over 400 years, the longest-living vertebrate known.

questions.question: What is the largest species of bear?
questions.explanation: Polar bears are the largest bears, with males weighing up to 1,500 pounds.

questions.question: How many legs does a spider have?
questions.explanation: All spiders have 8 legs. If it has 6 legs, it's an insect, not a spider.

questions.question: What is the fastest bird in a dive?
questions.explanation: Peregrine falcons can reach speeds over 200 mph during hunting dives.

questions.question: What animal has the highest blood pressure?
questions.explanation: Giraffes need very high blood pressure (about 280/180) to pump blood up their long necks to their brains.

questions.question: What is a group of lions called?
questions.explanation: A group of lions is called a pride. Groups of crows are murders, owls are parliaments.

questions.question: What is the largest living land animal?
questions.explanation: African elephants can weigh up to 14,000 pounds and stand 13 feet tall.

questions.question: How long is a giraffe's tongue?
questions.explanation: Giraffes have 18-20 inch tongues to help them reach leaves high in trees.

questions.question: What is the deadliest animal to humans?
questions.explanation: Mosquitoes kill over 700,000 people annually by spreading diseases like malaria.

questions.question: How many species of penguin are there?
questions.explanation: There are 18 species of penguin, all found in the Southern Hemisphere.

questions.question: What is the largest reptile?
questions.explanation: Saltwater crocodiles can grow over 20 feet long and weigh over 2,000 pounds.

questions.question: What bird has the largest wingspan?
questions.explanation: The wandering albatross has a wingspan up to 11 feet, the largest of any living bird.

questions.question: What is the largest cat species?
questions.explanation: Tigers are the largest cats, with males weighing up to 660 pounds.

questions.question: How many eyes does a bee have?
questions.explanation: Bees have 5 eyes: 2 compound eyes and 3 simple eyes.

questions.question: What is the smallest mammal?
questions.explanation: The bumblebee bat weighs only 2 grams and is about 1 inch long.

questions.question: What animal sleeps the most?
questions.explanation: Koalas sleep 18-22 hours per day to conserve energy from their low-nutrition eucalyptus diet.

questions.question: What is the chemical symbol for gold?
questions.explanation: Gold's symbol Au comes from the Latin word "aurum" meaning shining dawn.

questions.question: What is the most abundant element in the universe?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen makes up about 75% of all matter in the universe.

questions.question: What is the speed of light?
questions.explanation: Light travels at 299,792,458 meters per second (about 186,000 miles per second) in a vacuum.

questions.question: What is the periodic table?
questions.explanation: Organizes all known elements by atomic number, electron configuration, and recurring properties.

questions.question: What is H2O?
questions.explanation: Water is made of 2 hydrogen atoms and 1 oxygen atom.

questions.question: What gas do plants absorb from the atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Plants use CO2 during photosynthesis to make food and release oxygen.

questions.question: What is the hardest natural substance on Earth?
questions.explanation: Diamond scores 10 on the Mohs hardness scale, the hardest natural material.

questions.question: At what temperature does water boil?
questions.explanation: Water boils at 100°C or 212°F at standard atmospheric pressure.

questions.question: What is the chemical symbol for iron?
questions.explanation: Iron's symbol Fe comes from the Latin word "ferrum".

questions.question: What is the lightest element?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen is the simplest and lightest element with atomic number 1.

questions.question: What is the process of liquid turning to gas called?
questions.explanation: Evaporation is when a liquid becomes a gas at temperatures below boiling point.

questions.question: What is the pH of pure water?
questions.explanation: Pure water has a pH of 7, which is neutral (neither acidic nor basic).

questions.question: What is the atomic number of carbon?
questions.explanation: Carbon has 6 protons, making its atomic number 6.

questions.question: What are the three states of matter?
questions.explanation: The three common states are solid, liquid, and gas. Plasma is sometimes considered a fourth state.

questions.question: What gas makes up most of Earth's atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen makes up 78% of Earth's atmosphere, oxygen is only 21%.

questions.question: How many planets are in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune. Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.

questions.question: What is the largest planet in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Jupiter is so large that all other planets could fit inside it.

questions.question: What is the closest star to Earth?
questions.explanation: The Sun is our nearest star at 93 million miles away. The next closest is Proxima Centauri at 4.24 light-years.

questions.question: What galaxy do we live in?
questions.explanation: The Milky Way is a barred spiral galaxy containing 200-400 billion stars.

questions.question: What is the hottest planet in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Venus is hotter than Mercury despite being farther from the Sun, due to its thick atmosphere (900°F).

questions.question: How long does it take for Earth to orbit the Sun?
questions.explanation: Earth takes one year (365.25 days) to complete one orbit, which is why we have leap years.

questions.question: What is the largest moon in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Ganymede, a moon of Jupiter, is even larger than the planet Mercury.

questions.question: What is a black hole?
questions.explanation: When massive stars collapse, their gravity becomes so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape.

questions.question: What was the first animal in space?
questions.explanation: Soviet dog Laika was the first animal to orbit Earth in 1957 aboard Sputnik 2.

questions.question: How many moons does Mars have?
questions.explanation: Mars has two small moons: Phobos and Deimos, named after the Greek gods of fear and panic.

questions.question: What is the name of our nearest galaxy?
questions.explanation: The Andromeda Galaxy is 2.5 million light-years away and will collide with the Milky Way in 4.5 billion years.

questions.question: What is the Great Red Spot?
questions.explanation: A giant storm on Jupiter that has been raging for at least 300 years.

questions.question: Which planet has the most rings?
questions.explanation: Saturn has the most prominent ring system, though Jupiter, Uranus, and Neptune also have rings.

questions.question: What is a light-year?
questions.answer: Distance light travels in one year
questions.explanation: A light-year is about 6 trillion miles - the distance light travels in a year.

questions.question: What is the smallest planet in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Mercury is only slightly larger than Earth's moon.

questions.question: What causes earthquakes?
questions.explanation: Earth's crust is divided into plates that move and sometimes slip past each other.

questions.question: What scale measures earthquake strength?
questions.explanation: The Richter scale measures magnitude from 1-10, each number being 10x stronger.

questions.question: What causes lightning?
questions.explanation: Ice particles in clouds create electrical charges that discharge as lightning.

questions.question: What is the eye of a hurricane?
questions.explanation: The eye is a circular area of calm weather at the center of the hurricane.

questions.question: What causes seasons?
questions.explanation: Earth's 23.5° tilt causes different hemispheres to receive more/less sunlight throughout the year.

questions.question: What is the greenhouse effect?
questions.explanation: Greenhouse gases trap heat from the sun, warming Earth's surface.

questions.question: What type of rock is formed by volcanic activity?
questions.explanation: Igneous rocks form when molten rock (magma/lava) cools and solidifies.

questions.question: What is the water cycle?
questions.answer: Movement of water through evaporation, condensation, precipitation
questions.explanation: Water evaporates, forms clouds, falls as rain/snow, and returns to oceans/lakes.

questions.question: What instrument measures air pressure?
questions.explanation: Barometers measure atmospheric pressure, which helps predict weather changes.

questions.question: What is the ozone layer?
questions.explanation: The ozone layer absorbs most of the sun's harmful UV radiation.

questions.question: What causes tides?
questions.explanation: The moon's gravity pulls on Earth's oceans, creating high and low tides.

questions.question: What is photosynthesis?
questions.answer: Process plants use to make food from sunlight
questions.explanation: Plants convert CO2, water, and sunlight into glucose and oxygen.

questions.question: What is the largest rainforest?
questions.explanation: The Amazon produces 20% of the world's oxygen.

questions.question: What is a fossil fuel?
questions.explanation: Coal, oil, and natural gas formed from dead plants and animals over millions of years.

questions.question: What is El Niño?
questions.explanation: El Niño causes warmer water in the Pacific, affecting global weather patterns.

questions.question: What is the tallest type of tree?
questions.explanation: Coast redwoods can grow over 370 feet tall, the tallest trees on Earth.

questions.question: What gas do plants release during photosynthesis?
questions.explanation: Plants take in CO2 and release oxygen as a byproduct of photosynthesis.

questions.question: What is the largest flower in the world?
questions.explanation: Rafflesia can grow up to 3 feet wide and smells like rotting meat.

questions.question: What is a deciduous tree?
questions.answer: Tree that loses leaves in fall
questions.explanation: Deciduous trees shed leaves annually, unlike evergreens.

questions.question: What is a food chain?
questions.answer: Flow of energy through an ecosystem
questions.explanation: Energy moves from plants to herbivores to carnivores.

questions.question: What are producers in an ecosystem?
questions.answer: Organisms that make their own food (plants)
questions.explanation: Producers use photosynthesis to create energy from sunlight.

questions.question: What is biodiversity?
questions.answer: Variety of life in an ecosystem
questions.explanation: Higher biodiversity means more species and more stable ecosystems.

questions.question: What is a carnivore?
questions.explanation: Lions, sharks, and eagles are carnivores.

questions.question: What is pollination?
questions.answer: Transfer of pollen to fertilize plants
questions.explanation: Bees, butterflies, and wind help pollinate flowers.

questions.question: What is extinction?
questions.answer: When a species completely dies out
questions.explanation: Dinosaurs, dodos, and many other species have gone extinct.

questions.question: What is the capital of France?
questions.explanation: Paris has been the capital of France for over 1,000 years.

questions.question: What is the capital of Japan?
questions.explanation: Tokyo is the world's most populous metropolitan area with 37 million people.

questions.question: What is the capital of Australia?
questions.explanation: Canberra was chosen as a compromise between rivals Sydney and Melbourne.

questions.question: What is the capital of Canada?
questions.explanation: Ottawa was chosen by Queen Victoria in 1857 as Canada's capital.

questions.question: What is the capital of Brazil?
questions.explanation: Brasília was built from scratch in the interior and became capital in 1960.

questions.question: What is the capital of Egypt?
questions.explanation: Cairo is the largest city in Africa with over 20 million people.

questions.question: What is the capital of Germany?
questions.explanation: Berlin was divided during the Cold War and reunified in 1990.

questions.question: What is the capital of India?
questions.explanation: New Delhi was inaugurated as capital in 1931, replacing Calcutta.

questions.question: What is the capital of Italy?
questions.explanation: Rome has been continuously inhabited for over 2,800 years.

questions.question: What is the capital of Russia?
questions.explanation: Moscow is Europe's largest city with over 12 million residents.

questions.question: What is the capital of Spain?
questions.explanation: Madrid became the capital in 1561 under King Philip II.

questions.question: What is the capital of South Korea?
questions.explanation: Seoul is one of the world's most densely populated cities.

questions.question: What is the capital of Turkey?
questions.explanation: Ankara replaced Istanbul as capital in 1923 after Turkey became a republic.

questions.question: What is the capital of Thailand?
questions.explanation: Bangkok's ceremonial name is one of the world's longest place names.

questions.question: What is the capital of New Zealand?
questions.explanation: Wellington is the world's southernmost capital city.

questions.question: What is the largest country by area?
questions.explanation: Russia covers over 6.6 million square miles across 11 time zones.

questions.question: What is the smallest country in the world?
questions.explanation: Vatican City is only 0.17 square miles with about 800 residents.

questions.question: How many continents are there?
questions.explanation: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America.

questions.question: What is the most populous country?
questions.explanation: India surpassed China in 2023 with over 1.4 billion people.

questions.question: What country has the most islands?
questions.explanation: Sweden has over 267,000 islands, more than any other country.

questions.question: What is the longest country in the world?
questions.explanation: Chile stretches 2,670 miles from north to south but averages only 110 miles wide.

questions.question: Which continent has the most countries?
questions.explanation: Africa has 54 countries, more than any other continent.

questions.question: What country is also known as the Netherlands?
questions.explanation: Holland technically refers to only two provinces, but is commonly used for the whole country.

questions.question: What countries make up Scandinavia?
questions.explanation: The Nordic countries also include Finland and Iceland, but Scandinavia is specifically Norway, Sweden, and Denmark.

questions.question: What is the largest country in Africa?
questions.explanation: Algeria covers 919,595 square miles, making it Africa's largest country by area.

questions.question: What is the largest state by area?
questions.explanation: Alaska is 663,300 square miles, more than twice the size of Texas.

questions.question: What is the smallest state?
questions.explanation: Rhode Island is only 1,214 square miles.

questions.question: How many states are in the United States?
questions.explanation: The US has had 50 states since Hawaii joined in 1959.

questions.question: What is the capital of California?
questions.explanation: Sacramento became California's capital in 1854.

questions.question: What state is known as the Sunshine State?
questions.explanation: Florida adopted this nickname in 1970.

questions.question: What is the longest river in the US?
questions.explanation: The Missouri River is 2,341 miles long, slightly longer than the Mississippi.

questions.question: What are the Great Lakes?
questions.explanation: The five Great Lakes contain 84% of North America's surface fresh water.

questions.question: What state is Mount Rushmore in?
questions.explanation: Mount Rushmore features Washington, Jefferson, Teddy Roosevelt, and Lincoln.

questions.question: What is the most populous state?
questions.explanation: California has about 39 million people, 12% of the US population.

questions.question: What state is the Grand Canyon in?
questions.explanation: The Grand Canyon is 277 miles long and up to 18 miles wide.

questions.question: What is the tallest mountain in the world?
questions.explanation: Everest is 29,032 feet tall, on the Nepal-Tibet border.

questions.question: What is the longest river in the world?
questions.explanation: The Nile flows 4,135 miles through northeastern Africa.

questions.question: What is the largest ocean?
questions.explanation: The Pacific covers 63 million square miles, larger than all land areas combined.

questions.question: What is the largest desert?
questions.explanation: Antarctica is technically Earth's largest desert. The Sahara is the largest hot desert.

questions.question: What is the deepest ocean trench?
questions.explanation: The Mariana Trench is nearly 7 miles deep in the Pacific Ocean.

questions.question: What is the largest lake by area?
questions.explanation: Despite its name, the Caspian Sea is actually a lake covering 143,000 square miles.

questions.question: What is the highest waterfall in the world?
questions.explanation: Angel Falls in Venezuela drops 3,212 feet.

questions.question: What is the driest place on Earth?
questions.explanation: Parts of Chile's Atacama Desert haven't seen rain in over 400 years.

questions.question: What is the largest rainforest?
questions.explanation: The Amazon covers 2.1 million square miles across nine countries.

questions.question: What is the saltiest body of water?
questions.explanation: The Dead Sea is 34% salt, so dense you can float without effort.

questions.question: What country is the Great Wall in?
questions.explanation: The Great Wall of China stretches over 13,000 miles.

questions.question: What city is the Eiffel Tower in?
questions.explanation: The Eiffel Tower was built in 1889 for the World's Fair.

questions.question: What country are the Pyramids of Giza in?
questions.explanation: The pyramids were built as tombs for pharaohs around 2560 BC.

questions.question: What city is the Taj Mahal in?
questions.explanation: The Taj Mahal was built by Emperor Shah Jahan as a tomb for his wife.

questions.question: What country is Machu Picchu in?
questions.explanation: Machu Picchu was built by the Incas in the 15th century.

questions.question: What city is the Colosseum in?
questions.explanation: The Colosseum could hold 50,000-80,000 spectators for gladiator contests.

questions.question: What country is Stonehenge in?
questions.explanation: Stonehenge was built between 3000-2000 BC, its exact purpose remains debated.

questions.question: What city is Christ the Redeemer statue in?
questions.explanation: The 98-foot statue stands atop Corcovado mountain overlooking Rio.

questions.question: What country is Petra in?
questions.explanation: Petra was the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom, carved into red rock cliffs.

questions.question: What strait separates Europe and Africa?
questions.explanation: The strait is only 8 miles wide at its narrowest point.

questions.question: What is the largest tropical rainforest?
questions.explanation: The Amazon produces 20% of Earth's oxygen and spans 9 countries.

questions.question: What is the coldest continent?
questions.explanation: Antarctica has reached temperatures as low as -128.6°F.

questions.question: What country has the most active volcanoes?
questions.explanation: Indonesia has over 130 active volcanoes, part of the Ring of Fire.

questions.question: What is the wettest place on Earth?
questions.explanation: Mawsynram receives about 467 inches of rain annually.

questions.question: What mountain range separates Europe and Asia?
questions.explanation: The Urals stretch 1,600 miles through Russia.

questions.question: What movie won the first Academy Award for Best Picture?
questions.explanation: Wings (1927) was a WWI silent film about fighter pilots.

questions.question: Who directed Jaws, E.T., and Jurassic Park?
questions.explanation: Spielberg is one of the highest-grossing directors of all time.

questions.question: What 1977 film began with "A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away"?
questions.explanation: Star Wars became a cultural phenomenon and launched a massive franchise.

questions.question: What movie features the quote "Here's looking at you, kid"?
questions.explanation: Casablanca (1942) starred Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman.

questions.question: Who played Jack in Titanic?
questions.explanation: Titanic (1997) became the highest-grossing film of its time.

questions.question: What actor played Iron Man in the Marvel movies?
questions.explanation: RDJ launched the Marvel Cinematic Universe as Tony Stark in 2008.

questions.question: What movie features the song "My Heart Will Go On"?
questions.explanation: Celine Dion sang the iconic Titanic theme song.

questions.question: Who directed The Godfather?
questions.explanation: The Godfather (1972) is considered one of the greatest films ever made.

questions.question: What 1999 film questions the nature of reality with red and blue pills?
questions.explanation: The Matrix starred Keanu Reeves as Neo discovering the truth about reality.

questions.question: Who played Forrest Gump?
questions.explanation: Hanks won Best Actor for Forrest Gump (1994).

questions.question: What Disney movie features "Let It Go"?
questions.explanation: Frozen (2013) became a cultural phenomenon, especially with children.

questions.question: Who played Batman in The Dark Knight trilogy?
questions.explanation: Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy ran from 2005-2012.

questions.question: What 1975 musical film is set in the 1950s?
questions.explanation: Grease starred John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John.

questions.question: Who directed Pulp Fiction?
questions.explanation: Pulp Fiction (1994) is known for its nonlinear narrative.

questions.question: What 2019 film became the highest-grossing movie of all time?
questions.explanation: Endgame surpassed Avatar with $2.798 billion worldwide.

questions.question: Who is known as the King of Rock and Roll?
questions.explanation: Elvis revolutionized music in the 1950s with hits like "Hound Dog" and "Jailhouse Rock".

questions.question: What band was John Lennon in?
questions.explanation: The Beatles transformed popular music in the 1960s.

questions.question: Who sang "Thriller"?
questions.explanation: Thriller (1982) is the best-selling album of all time.

questions.question: What singer is known as the Queen of Pop?
questions.explanation: Madonna has been a pop icon since the 1980s with hits like "Like a Virgin" and "Vogue".

questions.question: Who sang "Purple Rain"?
questions.explanation: Prince's Purple Rain (1984) was both an album and a film.

questions.question: What band sang "Bohemian Rhapsody"?
questions.explanation: Queen's 1975 song became one of rock's most iconic tracks.

questions.question: Who is the best-selling female artist of all time?
questions.explanation: Madonna has sold over 300 million records worldwide.

questions.question: What rapper's real name is Marshall Mathers?
questions.explanation: Eminem became the best-selling artist of the 2000s.

questions.question: Who sang "Like a Rolling Stone"?
questions.explanation: Dylan's 1965 song is often called the greatest rock song ever.

questions.question: What band did Freddie Mercury lead?
questions.explanation: Mercury fronted Queen from 1970 until his death in 1991.

questions.question: Who sang "I Will Always Love You"?
questions.explanation: Houston's 1992 cover for The Bodyguard became iconic.

questions.question: What guitar legend played "Purple Haze"?
questions.explanation: Hendrix revolutionized electric guitar playing in the late 1960s.

questions.question: Who sang "Rolling in the Deep"?
questions.explanation: Adele's 2010 hit topped charts worldwide.

questions.question: What country singer sang "Jolene"?
questions.explanation: Parton wrote and recorded Jolene in 1973.

questions.question: Who is known as the Boss?
questions.explanation: Springsteen earned the nickname for his intense work ethic and lengthy shows.

questions.question: What long-running animated show features the Simpson family?
questions.explanation: The Simpsons debuted in 1989 and is the longest-running American sitcom.

questions.question: What HBO fantasy series is based on George R.R. Martin's novels?
questions.explanation: Game of Thrones ran from 2011-2019 and became a cultural phenomenon.

questions.question: What sitcom is set in Central Perk coffee shop?
questions.explanation: Friends ran from 1994-2004 and followed six friends in New York City.

questions.question: What show features chemistry teacher Walter White?
questions.explanation: Breaking Bad (2008-2013) followed a teacher turned meth manufacturer.

questions.question: What Netflix series is set in the 1980s in Hawkins, Indiana?
questions.explanation: Stranger Things debuted in 2016 featuring supernatural mysteries.

questions.question: What sitcom featured Jerry, George, Elaine, and Kramer?
questions.explanation: Seinfeld (1989-1998) was "a show about nothing" set in New York.

questions.question: What long-running sci-fi show features the TARDIS?
questions.explanation: Doctor Who has run since 1963, making it one of the longest-running sci-fi shows.

questions.question: What 1960s show featured Captain Kirk and Mr. Spock?
questions.explanation: Star Trek (1966-1969) launched a massive franchise.

questions.question: What show featured the phrase "How you doin'?"
questions.explanation: Joey Tribbiani's pickup line became iconic.

questions.question: What mockumentary sitcom is set in a paper company?
questions.explanation: The US Office (2005-2013) was based on the British series.

questions.question: What plumber is Nintendo's mascot?
questions.explanation: Mario debuted in Donkey Kong (1981) and got his own game in 1985.

questions.question: What block-building game became a cultural phenomenon?
questions.explanation: Minecraft (2011) became the best-selling video game of all time.

questions.question: What video game series features Master Chief?
questions.explanation: Halo revolutionized console first-person shooters starting in 2001.

questions.question: What battle royale game became huge in 2017?
questions.explanation: Fortnite popularized the battle royale genre and Floss dance.

questions.question: What social media platform uses hashtags and a bird logo?
questions.explanation: Twitter launched in 2006 and was rebranded to X in 2023.

questions.question: What video game franchise features Link and Zelda?
questions.explanation: Zelda debuted in 1986 and became one of Nintendo's biggest franchises.

questions.question: What game involves catching creatures in Poke Balls?
questions.explanation: Pokémon launched in 1996 and became a global phenomenon.

questions.question: What was the first video game character to have a balloon in the Macy's Thanksgiving Parade?
questions.explanation: Sonic appeared as a balloon in 1993.

questions.question: What social media platform is known for short videos and dances?
questions.explanation: TikTok exploded in popularity starting around 2018-2019.

questions.question: What game series features Grand Theft Auto?
questions.explanation: GTA is known for its open-world crime simulation gameplay.

questions.question: What video game console did Sony first release?
questions.explanation: The original PlayStation launched in 1994.

questions.question: What was Facebooks original name?
questions.explanation: Mark Zuckerberg launched TheFacebook at Harvard in 2004.

questions.question: What game popularized the first-person shooter genre?
questions.explanation: Doom (1993) revolutionized FPS gaming.

questions.question: What social media platform uses filters and the ghost logo?
questions.explanation: Snapchat launched in 2011, known for disappearing messages.

questions.question: What Nintendo character is a pink puffball?
questions.explanation: Kirby debuted in 1992 and can absorb enemies' powers.

questions.question: What city hosted the first modern Olympics?
questions.explanation: The first modern Olympics were held in Athens, Greece in 1896.

questions.question: How often are the Summer Olympics held?
questions.explanation: The Olympics have been held every 4 years since 1896, with exceptions for world wars.

questions.question: Who is the most decorated Olympian of all time?
questions.explanation: Phelps won 28 Olympic medals (23 gold) in swimming.

questions.question: What country has won the most Olympic gold medals all-time?
questions.explanation: The US has won over 1,000 gold medals across Summer Olympics.

questions.question: What do the five Olympic rings represent?
questions.explanation: The rings represent Africa, Americas, Asia, Europe, and Oceania.

questions.question: Who won four gold medals at the 1936 Olympics?
questions.explanation: Jesse Owens' victories in Nazi Germany defied Hitler's racial ideology.

questions.question: What city has hosted the Summer Olympics three times?
questions.explanation: London hosted in 1908, 1948, and 2012.

questions.question: What gymnast scored the first perfect 10 in Olympics?
questions.explanation: Comăneci scored a perfect 10 at age 14 in Montreal 1976.

questions.question: Who is considered the greatest basketball player of all time?
questions.explanation: Jordan won 6 NBA championships with the Chicago Bulls.

questions.question: How many players are on a basketball team on the court?
questions.explanation: Each team has 5 players on the court at a time.

questions.question: Who holds the NBA record for most points in a single game?
questions.explanation: Chamberlain scored 100 points for Philadelphia against New York in 1962.

questions.question: What team has won the most NBA championships?
questions.explanation: The Celtics have won 17 championships, tied with the Lakers.

questions.question: How many points is a shot from beyond the arc worth?
questions.explanation: The three-point line was added to the NBA in 1979.

questions.question: Who broke Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's all-time scoring record?
questions.explanation: LeBron passed Kareem's 38,387 points in 2023.

questions.question: What college basketball tournament is held each March?
questions.explanation: March Madness features 68 college teams competing for the championship.

questions.question: What country has won the most FIFA World Cups?
questions.explanation: Brazil has won 5 World Cups (1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, 2002).

questions.question: Who is the all-time leading scorer in World Cup history?
questions.explanation: Klose scored 16 goals across four World Cups for Germany.

questions.question: What is the most popular sport in the world?
questions.explanation: Soccer is played by over 250 million people in over 200 countries.

questions.question: Who won the 2022 FIFA World Cup?
questions.explanation: Argentina defeated France in the final, with Messi winning his first World Cup.

questions.question: How many players are on a soccer team on the field?
questions.explanation: Each team has 11 players including the goalkeeper.

questions.question: What English club has won the most Premier League titles?
questions.explanation: Manchester United has won 13 Premier League titles since 1992.

questions.question: Who is known as "The King of Football"?
questions.explanation: Pelé scored over 1,000 career goals and won 3 World Cups.

questions.question: What team has won the most Super Bowls?
questions.explanation: The Patriots have won 6 Super Bowls, tied with the Pittsburgh Steelers.

questions.question: Who is the NFL's all-time leading passer?
questions.explanation: Brady threw for over 89,000 yards in his career.

questions.question: How many points is a touchdown worth?
questions.explanation: A touchdown is 6 points, plus teams can score 1 or 2 on the conversion.

questions.question: What trophy do Super Bowl winners receive?
questions.explanation: Named after the legendary Packers coach who won the first two Super Bowls.

questions.question: How many Super Bowl rings does Tom Brady have?
questions.explanation: Brady won 6 with New England and 1 with Tampa Bay.

questions.question: What college football team has won the most national championships?
questions.explanation: Alabama has claimed 18 national championships.

questions.question: Who holds the MLB record for most home runs in a career?
questions.explanation: Bonds hit 762 home runs, though the record is controversial due to steroid allegations.

questions.question: What team has won the most World Series championships?
questions.explanation: The Yankees have won 27 World Series titles.

questions.question: How many strikes does it take to strike out a batter?
questions.explanation: Three strikes and you're out is a fundamental baseball rule.

questions.question: Who broke Babe Ruth's home run record?
questions.explanation: Aaron passed Ruth's 714 home runs in 1974, finishing with 755.

questions.question: What is it called when a player hits a single, double, triple, and home run in one game?
questions.explanation: Hitting for the cycle is a rare baseball accomplishment.

questions.question: How many innings are in a regulation baseball game?
questions.explanation: Baseball games are 9 innings unless tied, then they go to extra innings.

questions.question: What is a perfect game in baseball?
questions.answer: No hits, walks, or runs allowed
questions.explanation: A pitcher must retire all 27 batters without anyone reaching base.

questions.question: What does RBI stand for?
questions.explanation: An RBI is credited when a batter's hit causes a run to score.

questions.question: Who is known as "The Sultan of Swat"?
questions.explanation: Ruth revolutionized baseball in the 1920s with his power hitting.

questions.question: What is the distance from the pitcher's mound to home plate?
questions.explanation: This distance has been standard since 1893.

questions.question: What is a no-hitter?
questions.answer: Game where pitcher allows no hits
questions.explanation: Walks and errors are allowed, but no batter gets a hit.

questions.question: How many players are on a baseball field?
questions.explanation: Each team has 9 defensive players on the field.

questions.question: What is the seventh-inning stretch?
questions.answer: Traditional break in middle of 7th inning
questions.explanation: Fans stand and sing "Take Me Out to the Ball Game".

questions.question: Who has the most career hits in MLB history?
questions.explanation: Rose had 4,256 hits but was banned from baseball for gambling.

questions.question: How many Grand Slam tournaments are there in tennis?
questions.explanation: Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, and US Open.

questions.question: What is a hole-in-one in golf?
questions.answer: Hitting ball from tee into hole in one stroke
questions.explanation: A rare and celebrated golf achievement.

questions.question: Who has won the most Grand Slam singles titles?
questions.explanation: Djokovic has 24 Grand Slam titles (as of 2024).

questions.question: What is par in golf?
questions.answer: Expected number of strokes for a hole
questions.explanation: Scoring below par (birdie, eagle) is good; above par (bogey) is bad.

questions.question: What is deuce in tennis?
questions.explanation: A player must win by two points after deuce.

questions.question: Who is known as "The Golden Bear" in golf?
questions.explanation: Nicklaus won 18 major championships, a record until recently.

questions.question: What is love in tennis scoring?
questions.explanation: Tennis scores go 0 (love), 15, 30, 40, game.

questions.question: What is the Masters Tournament?
questions.explanation: Held annually in Georgia, winner receives a green jacket.

questions.question: Who has won the most Wimbledon men's titles?
questions.explanation: Federer won 8 Wimbledon titles from 2003-2017.

questions.question: What is an ace in tennis?
questions.explanation: A perfectly placed serve that scores immediately.

questions.question: What is the most famous auto race in the world?
questions.explanation: The Indy 500 has been held annually since 1911.

questions.question: What sport uses a puck?
questions.explanation: Ice hockey is played with a hard rubber puck.

questions.question: What is Formula 1?
questions.explanation: F1 races on circuits around the world with the fastest cars.

questions.question: How many players are on an ice hockey team?
questions.explanation: Each team has 6 players on ice: 3 forwards, 2 defensemen, 1 goalie.

questions.question: What is the Tour de France?
questions.explanation: Multi-stage race through France lasting about 3 weeks.

questions.question: What sport is played at Wimbledon?
questions.explanation: Wimbledon is the oldest tennis tournament, dating to 1877.

questions.question: What is a hat trick in hockey?
questions.answer: Scoring three goals in one game
questions.explanation: Fans traditionally throw hats on the ice to celebrate.

questions.question: Who is considered the greatest boxer of all time?
questions.explanation: Ali was heavyweight champion and cultural icon.

questions.question: Who wrote Romeo and Juliet?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare wrote the tragic love story around 1594-1596.

questions.question: Who wrote Pride and Prejudice?
questions.explanation: Austen's 1813 novel follows Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy.

questions.question: Who wrote 1984?
questions.explanation: Orwell's dystopian novel was published in 1949.

questions.question: Who wrote To Kill a Mockingbird?
questions.explanation: Lee's 1960 novel addresses racial injustice in the American South.

questions.question: Who wrote The Great Gatsby?
questions.explanation: Fitzgerald's 1925 novel explores the American Dream in the Jazz Age.

questions.question: Who wrote Moby-Dick?
questions.explanation: Melville's 1851 novel follows Captain Ahab's obsession with a white whale.

questions.question: Who wrote War and Peace?
questions.explanation: Tolstoy's epic 1869 novel chronicles Russian society during the Napoleonic Wars.

questions.question: Who wrote The Odyssey?
questions.explanation: Homer's ancient Greek epic follows Odysseus' journey home after the Trojan War.

questions.question: Who wrote Jane Eyre?
questions.explanation: Brontë's 1847 novel follows an orphaned governess.

questions.question: Who wrote The Catcher in the Rye?
questions.explanation: Salinger's 1951 novel follows teenager Holden Caulfield.

questions.question: Who wrote Frankenstein?
questions.explanation: Shelley wrote the Gothic novel in 1818 at age 18.

questions.question: Who wrote The Divine Comedy?
questions.explanation: Dante's 14th-century epic poem describes a journey through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise.

questions.question: Who wrote Crime and Punishment?
questions.explanation: Dostoevsky's 1866 novel explores morality through the story of Raskolnikov.

questions.question: Who wrote The Iliad?
questions.explanation: Homer's epic poem recounts the Trojan War.

questions.question: Who wrote Wuthering Heights?
questions.explanation: Emily Brontë's only novel (1847) is a Gothic romance.

questions.question: Who wrote Harry Potter?
questions.explanation: Rowling's series (1997-2007) follows a young wizard at Hogwarts.

questions.question: Who wrote The Cat in the Hat?
questions.explanation: Dr. Seuss wrote 60+ children's books with distinctive rhyming style.

questions.question: Who wrote Charlotte's Web?
questions.explanation: White's 1952 novel tells the story of a pig named Wilbur and spider Charlotte.

questions.question: Who wrote The Hunger Games?
questions.explanation: Collins' dystopian trilogy (2008-2010) follows Katniss Everdeen.

questions.question: Who wrote Where the Wild Things Are?
questions.explanation: Sendak's 1963 picture book follows Max's wild imagination.

questions.question: Who wrote The Chronicles of Narnia?
questions.explanation: Lewis wrote 7 fantasy novels starting with The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (1950).

questions.question: Who wrote Matilda?
questions.explanation: Dahl's 1988 novel features a brilliant girl with telekinetic powers.

questions.question: Who wrote The Giving Tree?
questions.explanation: Silverstein's 1964 picture book explores selflessness.

questions.question: Who wrote The Handmaid's Tale?
questions.explanation: Atwood's 1985 dystopian novel depicts a totalitarian theocracy.

questions.question: Who wrote The Da Vinci Code?
questions.explanation: Brown's 2003 thriller follows symbologist Robert Langdon.

questions.question: Who wrote The Kite Runner?
questions.explanation: Hosseini's 2003 novel follows friendship in Afghanistan.

questions.question: Who wrote Gone Girl?
questions.explanation: Flynn's 2012 thriller explores a marriage gone wrong.

questions.question: Who wrote The Road?
questions.explanation: McCarthy's 2006 post-apocalyptic novel won the Pulitzer Prize.

questions.question: Who wrote Life of Pi?
questions.explanation: Martel's 2001 novel follows a boy surviving at sea with a tiger.

questions.question: Who wrote The Shining?
questions.explanation: King's 1977 horror novel is set in the Overlook Hotel.

questions.question: Who wrote "The Raven"?
questions.explanation: Poe's 1845 narrative poem features the refrain "Nevermore".

questions.question: Who wrote Hamlet?
questions.explanation: Hamlet features the famous line "To be or not to be".

questions.question: Who wrote "The Road Not Taken"?
questions.explanation: Frost's 1916 poem reflects on choices: "Two roads diverged in a yellow wood".

questions.question: Who wrote A Streetcar Named Desire?
questions.explanation: Williams' 1947 play features Blanche DuBois and Stanley Kowalski.

questions.question: Who wrote Death of a Salesman?
questions.explanation: Miller's 1949 play follows Willy Loman's tragic life.

questions.question: Who wrote Macbeth?
questions.explanation: Macbeth explores ambition and guilt with the famous "Out, damned spot!" line.

questions.question: Who wrote "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening"?
questions.explanation: Frost's 1923 poem ends with "And miles to go before I sleep".

questions.question: Who wrote Othello?
questions.explanation: Othello is a tragedy about jealousy and manipulation.

questions.question: Who wrote "The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock"?
questions.explanation: Eliot's 1915 modernist poem influenced 20th century poetry.

questions.question: Who wrote A Raisin in the Sun?
questions.explanation: Hansberry's 1959 play explores an African-American family in Chicago.

questions.question: Who wrote "The Waste Land"?
questions.explanation: Eliot's 1922 poem is a modernist masterpiece about post-WWI disillusionment.

questions.question: Who wrote Romeo and Juliet?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare's tragic love story features feuding families in Verona.

questions.question: Who wrote "Howl"?
questions.explanation: Ginsberg's 1956 Beat Generation poem challenged censorship laws.

questions.question: Who wrote The Crucible?
questions.explanation: Miller's 1953 play about Salem witch trials was an allegory for McCarthyism.

questions.question: Who wrote "If—"?
questions.explanation: Kipling's 1910 inspirational poem advises "If you can keep your head when all about you are losing theirs".

questions.question: Who wrote The Diary of a Young Girl?
questions.explanation: Anne Frank's diary documented her life hiding from Nazis during WWII.

questions.question: Who wrote The Autobiography of Malcolm X?
questions.explanation: Published in 1965, it chronicles Malcolm X's life and transformation.

questions.question: Who wrote Silent Spring?
questions.explanation: Carson's 1962 book launched the environmental movement by exposing pesticide dangers.

questions.question: Who wrote A Brief History of Time?
questions.explanation: Hawking's 1988 book explains cosmology for general readers.

questions.question: Who wrote The Origin of Species?
questions.explanation: Darwin's 1859 book introduced the theory of evolution by natural selection.

questions.question: Who wrote Walden?
questions.explanation: Thoreau's 1854 book reflects on simple living in nature.

questions.question: Who wrote I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings?
questions.explanation: Angelou's 1969 autobiography covers her early years and overcoming racism.

questions.question: Who wrote Night?
questions.explanation: Wiesel's 1960 memoir describes his experiences in Nazi concentration camps.
